article_title: East Texans line up for hours, some overnight, to get free dental and vision services during clinic
article_text:
Mary Tyson, 52, of Eustace, made it to Tyler just before 3 a.m. Friday to get help for her painful teeth at the East Texas Mission of Mercy’s dental and vision clinic - a biennial event that provides much-needed services for low-income East Texans.

She was among the first 207 people who lined up in the Bethesda Health Clinic parking lot. Some people had camped out as early as Thursday afternoon, anxious to get a spot to be seen. Volunteers said about 139 were there before 2:50 a.m., right before they started passing out tickets for screenings.

After getting ticket No. 142, Ms. Tyson returned to her car for a nap. By 7:20 a.m., she was back in line preparing to get registered but was bumped up about 17 places because some patients had not returned.

Two teeth on her left side had been bothering her for about two weeks. She has to eat on the right side, and chewing tough meat is out of the question. Even eating a banana on her 45-minute drive over made her teeth throb with pain.

“Gradually, it seems to get worse,” she said.

She has only 14 teeth left and three of those are broken.

“I have two on the top - that’s it,” she said. “I wish I could get them all pulled and get dentures.”

Once volunteers starting calling numbers, patients registered under a large tent outside. They then were triaged inside the clinic. The small space was packed with medical volunteers scurrying to see each patient, as virtually every wall was lined with people sitting and waiting.

Patients there to have their eyes checked received services on Friday, but most dental patients would get extractions, root canals and other work done at various locations on Saturday.

About 350 medical and nonmedical volunteers helped coordinate the event, which was done in partnership with the Texas Dental Association, Bethesda Health Clinic, Tyler Junior College, Marvin United Church and several local clinics. TJC’s dental hygiene students and dental students from Texas A&M University Baylor College of Dentistry also showed up to help.

Amber Busby, adjunct professor at TJC’s dental assistant program, was among the many volunteers, including two dentists, from the college.

“It’s a great thing what they do in the community,” she said of organizers.

Judging by the x-rays she’d seen in the morning, Ms. Busby said most patients who showed up needed extractions and some may have an “active infection.”

Most of the people at the free clinic every other year are not regular Bethesda patients, but later seek services there. Clinic staff said about half of their dental patients have been referred from the biennial clinic.

Bethesda depends on local dentists to provide care each weekday. Saturday clinics also are planned. There, patients can get dental work for about $40. They estimate there were more than 4,000 dental visits last year.

ACCESS AND DOLLARS

One-third of American adults have untreated tooth decay, while one in seven age 35 to 44 has gum disease, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Since dental care typically hasn’t been seen as a required benefit of health insurance plans and was left out of the Affordable Care Act for adults, those with a lower socioeconomic status may go years without addressing potential problems.

Much like the medically uninsured showing up in the emergency room when it’s no longer possible to wait, low-income patients with dental problems also seek emergency treatment when disease has advanced.

“It’s something that has to be addressed, because it can impact people’s health,” said Dr. John English, executive director at Bethesda Health Clinic. “The problem is dollars and cents.”

Getting the one-time help at a free clinic is critical, but with complex cases, patients may need additional procedures and services, requiring them to return to a dentist office regularly until the problem is resolved. Deep cleaning, to address periodontal disease, could be costly.

“It could be thousands of dollars without insurance,” Ms. Busby said. “It could run about $3,000 plus the cost of extractions.”

Ms. Tyson is unable to work and is on disability, mostly due to a back injury and circulation problems caused by diabetes. She hasn’t had dental insurance for years. Diabetes and being a 30-year smoker compound her poor oral health.

After about six hours, Ms. Tyson was finally seen by dental staff, who took three x-rays. An oral surgeon wanted to get good photos. With the presence of a lesion, coupled with the fact that she’s a smoker, the surgeon recommended she get a biopsy to screen for oral cancer. She said a knot had been on her gums for about two years.

“I hope they do it today,” she said, as she waited for the next instructions.

Dentists didn’t perform any procedures on Ms. Tyson Friday, but her dental problems will be addressed at 11 a.m. Saturday at TJC, the appointment given to her by volunteers on her last stop at the clinic.

Although tired, she was optimistic when she left just after 10 a.m. Friday - about seven hours after she arrived. Still in pain, she smiled knowing she’d get some help soon.

“I just want it to quit hurting,” she said.

article_summary:
She was among the first 207 people who lined up in the Bethesda Health Clinic parking lot.
Clinic staff said about half of their dental patients have been referred from the biennial clinic.
“It’s something that has to be addressed, because it can impact people’s health,” said Dr. John English, executive director at Bethesda Health Clinic.
After about six hours, Ms. Tyson was finally seen by dental staff, who took three x-rays.
142, Ms. Tyson returned to her car for a nap.
